welcome to the spice islands cafe, downtown mountain view.

malaysian style coconut scallops, beef rendang, nasi lemak, coconut rice, shrimp rolls, basil chicken and malaysian style spareribs.

mmm.

I hate election day this year. It leaves me with this sick feeling in the pit of my stomach because of the future I know is coming yet I am still optimistic and hope for the best.

It's funny and sad at the same time, I guess, and I'm really not sure what to think of it all. There are moments when I'm filled with happiness, like the moment my mother told me she was going to register to vote. My mother, of all people, who has always said her vote doesn't count. There are hundreds of thousands, even millions of people like this who think the same, but this time around they've changed their minds.

Whether it's blind faith, logic and reasoning, love and compassion or hatred and fear that drive them to the polls, people are spilling out by numbers never seen before to make themselves part of the vaguely democratic process of choosing our next employee of the year, the guy who is supposed to do stuff for us, our next President.

Then there are moments that sadden me, like when I can't make a blind-faith Bushie see logic, and regardless of conceding to my points of logic they say "But I'm voting for him anyway". It makes me wonder deep inside if there is something else I could've done. But I know there isn't. After all, if one isn't willing to listen to logic after admitting you are wrong, then what else can be done to change your mind?

So, today is the day. The day the people will voice their opinion on whether or not they wish to continue to follow this blind path of darkness lead by GWB, or if they choose to venture along the unknown trail, realizing that things could be worse but how could they not be at least a little better? This is one of the most historic election days of our times- not just in the decision made but the fact that so many wanted their decision to be known.

But what will happen, is the question? Predicted by myself and a couple of others, despite the rallying support for Kerry, mitigating factors will cause Bush to win his second term. This second term will lead us further into war and strife in the middle east and see a rise in terrorism at home which will result in further fascist policy being made and approved. 

The citizenry won't stand for it, of course, and it will result in at least civil unrest but at worst civil war, sending the world into a new dark age as a great majority of economies are dependent on our own.

Rising from the ashes of this civil unrest will be corporations, the giant teddy bears here to coddle you with soothing shiny products of epic expenditure and indenture you to their servitude in the name of making more money for whomever is on top. 

I hope Kerry wins. Don't you?

Sitting at my friend's dance recital, I had a moment of introspection. Not one of your usual moments of introspection that you have while you're on the can and didn't have any reading material to bring in with you, but the kind of profound yet possibly completely unproductive moments of introspection you have when your brain strings together a sequence of relations that you never thought your mind capable of stringing together.

After all, you still couldn't figure out who shot who on that soap opera, right?

So I'm sitting there watching 14 year old girls ballet and after a long sequence of relational thoughts in my head in a brief period of time, I come to a conclusion.

Age makes you lose your optimism, which in turn affects your ability to do new stuff.

<lj-cut text="Read more bullshit homebrew philosophy or whatever it is.">

See, they say that you learn languages best when you're a little kid. You also learn performance ability best when you're a little kid. Certain things you just have a real hard time learning when you get older, and why?

Self-consciousness and self-doubt.

Sure, you may still have optimism, you may still think world peace is possible and just around the corner. But in the end, the older you get, the more self-consciousness and self-doubt you accrue. Kind of like properties in monopoly, except you don't get any money back when someone lands on your self-doubt neighborhood. You just run and hide with a really red face.

I wonder if there are things I'll never be able to learn. I'm a firm believer that it's possible for anybody to learn anything, so long as they have a normal brain and are given the proper basic training in logical thought and music. Both are very important. 

I want to learn new languages. I want to act in a movie. I want to perform on stage with a band. I want to write something that gets published in a national newspaper. I want to produce and direct a movie. I want to learn how to sing better. I want to learn how to dance. There are plenty of things I want to learn how to do and you know, I think the only ones I'll accomplish are those that don't require overcoming that self-doubt and self-consciousness.

Speaking another language can be hard. You're very self-conscious about how you say what you say becaue you'd prefer not sounding like an idiot. Dancing? You don't want to look like an idiot. Writing? Acting? Same and same. It's not stage-fright. It's self-doubt.

I just want to stay optimistic. I don't want to become some crotchety old man waving an I Love Bush sign on the street corner. I want to stay being -me-, and I want to do and learn the things that I want to do.

Anybody can do anything, given the proper basic training and the ability to overcome self-doubt.

Sigh.

Or Le Sigh as a certain somebody might say.

So, I apologize for this tangent. It's just something I thought of. On a side note, my friend is an incredible dancer. You can really tell she loves what she does and could die happy living it every day of her life. I envy that passion. Her form and style is just.. wowsers. I found myself completely enamored with her ability to dance.

On top of that, I have trips to plan. Chicago on Halloween, Indianapolis in July, Vegas in August and October. And I want to visit NYC in December.

Anyone wanna come with to Chi-town or NYC? :)

</lj-cut>

There are times where the planets align, stars come into conjunction with galaxies far and wide, miracles and voodoo hexes both occur simultaneously and you're left with what the rest of the world refers to as a Bad Day&trade. Only, your Bad Day&trade feels different than normal bad days. This is a day where you feel riddled with depression and you're not quite certain where it came from. Much like a dozen fresh illegal Mexican immigrants in LA, it arrived overnight without any warning of how. What triggered it? Cosmic forces? Bad breakfast cereal? Painful reminders. Ah yes. Those. They're usually the catalyst in the evil biochemical reaction that results in a heavy feeling of depression. Painful reminders of what? Strangely enough and despite my stunning ability to exist and operate willfully in my somewhat hermitlike existence, the painful reminders of being undesirable. Things people say or do, being just a friend or big brother, all those things leave you with that heavy feeling. And no, I'm not talking about you, you Russian poolshark minx. You had nothing to do with this, honestly. ;) Don't get me wrong. I have little to no problem finding means to engage in carnal indulgences with fairly attractive members of the opposite sex, and I do so on a frequent enough basis to keep the instinctual animal hidden within sated. Hell, I've even been complimented more than once on my ability to seduce a woman. That's great. But when the ones you really wanted are always going to other people because you are a better friend than anything else (read: not attractive to them in any way), it leaves you with a seed of discontent with yourself. When it happens twice in one day and then another 'friend' calls to tell you about her new boyfriend that's mistreating her, it becomes a full-fledged demonspawn discontent tree. With black christmas lights and everything. So, for now, I will sit and simmer my discontent with some garlic and basil over a medium heat and spend some time with some friends distracting myself from the burning smell in the kitchen until it goes away or the fire department comes by to put out the charred remains of my mind. Depression happens, folks. It's just the way it is. It's what happens when you attempt to fight social programming and human nature to be a social, loved, and cared-for creature and instead desire to become a fully independent self-willed man with no need or reliance on that external sensory input. Except for blowjobs, okay? Those are still fucking great.

The blockbuster video at Santa Teresa and Blossom Hill is closing soon, to be replaced by some fine eatery of yuppie proportions that only the extremely middle middle-class can appreciate.
